- The cause of the derailment was under investigation by the NTSB, but board member Michael Graham said on Sunday that video footage of the accident pointed to possible 'mechanical issues on one of the rail car axles.' correction_response:
This tweet is potentially misleading. The toxic waste from the derailment near East Palestine was indeed a concern, but it was handled in a controlled manner by experts and first responders. They prepared drainage pits and embankments to contain the residue and monitored the air quality throughout the process. The operation was completed successfully, reducing the risk of contamination to the Ohio River. Please refer to these articles for more information: 
https://www.reuters.com/world/us/ohio-carry-out-controlled-release-chemicals-train-derailment-site-2023-02-06/
note_1_text: The map is of the Ohio River Basin and does not accurately represent areas of potentially contaminated drinking water.    Multiple agencies and locales are actively testing ground and river-based drinking water and have found no contamination.    https://www.wlwt.com/article/cincinnati-water-works-water-quality-train-derailment/42837092  https://wvmetronews.com/2023/02/13/wvawc-installs-temporary-intake-on-guyandotte-river/  https://www.timesleaderonline.com/news/local-news/2023/02/ohio-river-being-tested-for-chemicals-from-derailment/  https://www.wtap.com/2023/02/13/train-derailment-prompts-water-utility-take-precautions/
note_2_text: This map shows the Ohio River Basin, which is the area of land that eventually drains into the Ohio River. This has no correlation to where towns source their drinking water from, which is often an upstream tributary or lake.
